T1548: Adversaries may circumvent mechanisms designed to control elevate privileges to gain higher-level permissions
T1548.001: An adversary may abuse configurations where an application has the setuid or setgid bits set in order to get code running in a different (and possibly more privileged) user’s context
T1548.002: Adversaries may bypass UAC mechanisms to elevate process privileges on system
T1548.003: Adversaries may perform sudo caching and/or use the sudoers file to elevate privileges
T1548.004: Adversaries may leverage the AuthorizationExecuteWithPrivileges API to escalate privileges by prompting the user for credentials
T1548.005: Adversaries may abuse permission configurations that allow them to gain temporarily elevated access to cloud resources
T1134: Adversaries may modify access tokens to operate under a different user or system security context to perform actions and bypass access controls
T1134.001: Adversaries may duplicate then impersonate another user's existing token to escalate privileges and bypass access controls
T1134.002: Adversaries may create a new process with an existing token to escalate privileges and bypass access controls
T1134.003: Adversaries may make new tokens and impersonate users to escalate privileges and bypass access controls
T1134.004: Adversaries may spoof the parent process identifier (PPID) of a new process to evade process-monitoring defenses or to elevate privileges
T1134.005: Adversaries may use SID-History Injection to escalate privileges and bypass access controls
T1197: Adversaries may abuse BITS jobs to persistently execute code and perform various background tasks
T1612: Adversaries may build a container image directly on a host to bypass defenses that monitor for the retrieval of malicious images from a public registry
T1622: Adversaries may employ various means to detect and avoid debuggers
T1140: Adversaries may use Obfuscated Files or Information to hide artifacts of an intrusion from analysis
T1610: Adversaries may deploy a container into an environment to facilitate execution or evade defenses
T1006: Adversaries may directly access a volume to bypass file access controls and file system monitoring
T1484: Adversaries may modify the configuration settings of a domain to evade defenses and/or escalate privileges in domain environments
T1484.001: Adversaries may modify Group Policy Objects (GPOs) to subvert the intended discretionary access controls for a domain, usually with the intention of escalating privileges on the domain
